description: From Middle English pevische, pevisse, pevysse, peivesshe, also peyuesshe, peeuish, of obscure origin. Perhaps from Middle English pew, pue (“a plaintive cry, the cry of a bird”), equivalent to pue +‎ -ish. Cognate with Scots pevis, pevess, pevych, pevach (“peevish”), Scots pew, peu (“to cry in a plaintive manner”). See pue.
An alternative etymology derives Middle English peyvesshe (“capricious, silly”), as a possible corruption of Latin perversus (“perverted”). The meaning “fretful” develops in the 16th century.

A third suggestion links the word to classical Latin expavidus (“startled, shy”) (< ex- + pavidus) via an unrecorded variant with -ai- of Middle French espave (“stray [of animals]; foreign [of persons]; lost property, flotsam”) (first attested 1283 in Old French; Modern French épave). The semantic connection is thought to be the behaviour of stray animals. Compare -ish suffix.

adjectives.description: peevish (comparative more peevish, superlative most peevish)

entries.meaning: Characterized by or exhibiting petty bad temper, bad-tempered, moody, cross. [from 1520]
examples: I would rather figure things out on my own than ask that peevish librarian for help.
There were several peevish patients in the doctor's waiting room.

entries.meaning: Easily annoyed, especially by things that are not important; irritable, querulous.
examples: At first he was quite peevish. “What's the idea,” he said, “coming and spoiling a man's beauty-sleep? Get out.”
The word peevish among the vulgar of Scotland is used for niggardly, covetous; in the North of England, for witty, subtile.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, Canada, Northern England) Sharp, piercing, bitter (of the wind); windy, blustery (of the weather).
examples: […]  the ridge  […]  /  […]  defends you from the blust'ring north, / And bleak affliction of the peevish east.

entries.meaning: (chiefly obsolete) Perverse, refractory; headstrong, obstinate; capricious, skittish; (also) coy. [from c. 1400]
examples: Not onely foolyshe frowarde and obstinate but also peuysshe, peruerse and indurate.
This is your peeuish chattering weake old man.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Beside oneself; out of one's senses; mad. [16th c.]
examples: Some tremblid, some girnid, some gaspid, some gasid, As people halfe peuysshe, or men that were masyd.
In derision of the king, they made certaine peeuishe and mocking rymes which I passe ouer.
The Lords Supper and your peevish, popish private masse doe agree together..as the common proverbe is, like harpe and harrow, or like the hare and the hound.
